Here's the article: http://techcrunch.com/2016/06/08/twitter-hack/
Twitter denies it (also they bcrypt their passwords anyway). TechCrunch says the website that claims this leak is legit is LeakedSource, where you can check if your credentials have been leaked, though I wouldn't recommend that; you'd probably search using more than one parameter (saying a username and a phone number, or your username and email, etc) so you'd be basically giving away data about your accounts that could help someone hack into them anyway.

Also, recovering a password from a salted hash isn't impossible, it just takes a lot (A LOT) of time/resources per hash, depending on the algorithm/iteration counts/etc etc. But then again, there is no way they'd just magically recover 30-something million salted and hashed passwords overnight lol

"Based on information in the data (including the fact that many of the passwords are displayed in plaintext), LeakedSource believes that the user credentials were collected by malware infecting browsers like Firefox or Chrome rather than stolen directly from Twitter.
